Issues.Title: Radio buttons not applying attr.name when using [name] binding
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When binding to radio inputs, using `[name]="myNameVariable"` does not apply the attr.name value, meaning the tab order does not work. Using only `[attr.name]="myNameVariable"` results in only the native attribute being set and so all radio groups have the same name as far as the form control is concerned.

The two solutions to this are to use both `[name]` and `[attr.name]` together, or to just use ~~name="{{myNameVariable}}"~~ (just found out while writing this that only `name="nonVariableString"` will set both the attr.name and ng-reflect, using `{{}}` interpolation doesn't work making this extra annoying) which sets both values. This is strange behaviour that isn't immediately obvious. Ideally `[name]` should also set attr.name as well as the ng-reflect.

I will be honest I am not sure what is happening behind the scenes with this component so I'm not even sure if this is possible or desired but its confusing when standard attribute names are hijacked for angular specific implementation and it prevents the native html from working.

Issues.Title: build: ensure script that build the Zone.js package can be run from any directory
Issues.Body:
The scripts that build the Angular and Zone.js NPM packages rely on absolute paths in order to work correctly regardless of what the current working directory is when the scripts are invoked. However, the `npm pack` command executed in the `zone-js-builder.js` script outputs the generated `.tgz` archive in the current working directory. This causes the script to fail when invoked for any working directory other than the project root directory.

This commit fixes this by ensuring the `npm pack` command is run with the project root directory as the working directory. This allows the build scripts to run correctly regardless of the working directory they are invoked from.

Issues.Title: Ivy LS: Context determination (for local completions)
Issues.Body:
The "old" LS and the current state of the Ivy LS determine (or [will determine, per Alex's work](https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/39250/files)) the kinds of completions to provide based on what node in the syntax tree the user's cursor position is in. This method falls apart when we want to generate context-sensitive completions, for instance w.r.t. a pipe:

```
{ a | ¬¶ }}
  ^^^     binding pipe span
 ^^^^^^^  interpolation span
```

The cursor lands in the interpolation, not the pipe, so in the present state, we would provide general interpolation (expression) completions. But clearly, what we really want is completions for pipes.

Thus I propose that what we want to do for completions requests is not find the "narrowest" node a cursor is in, but find the "context" node of a cursor - namely the node the cursor is "closest to".

Suppose the Angular syntax tree consisted of individual tokens. Then it would be more or less straightforward - just find the nearest token to the left of the cursor, and walk up the token productions if you need an AST node. But okay, our AST has no notion of this, so we need to do something else. Here is my progression of thoughts, with idea 3 being the one I suggest moving forward:

- Idea 1: when we land in a node, look if there is a child of that node we can ‚Äúpull back‚Äù to 
  Looking at `{ a | ¬¶ }}`, we can say okay, we landed in an interpolation, let's see if the interpolation expression has a child we don't fit in but could if we provided completions for. In this case we would find the child `a |` and could "pull back" to it as our context.
But this quickly falls apart, for example consider  `{{ a | b: 1 + ¬¶  }}`: we would expect our context to be the empty expression on the rhs of `1 +`, but that is a nested child of the `BindingPipe` which we would see as the sole child of the interpolation we landed in.

- Idea 2: always look for nearest-left-ended node, fallback on narrowest node
  Okay, so maybe we should always just look for nodes that end before the present cursor location. Trying a few examples, this seems to work:
  - `{{ a | b: 1 + ¬¶  }}` finds the empty expression on the RHS of `1 +` as expected
  - `{{ (a | ¬¶ ) + 1 }}` finds the pipe `a |` as expect
  - `{{ ¬¶a = 1 }}` has no nearest node that ended before the cursor, so we fall back on the narrowest node and get a property write, which is OK
  But this idea also quickly falls apart:
  - `{{ a | b: (¬¶) }}` would find the property read `a` as the nearest-left-ended node, but we want to land in the empty expression in `()`
  - `"a = 1; b = ¬¶2"` doesn‚Äôt work either, we would find `a = 1` as our context node, but this is clearly incorrect.

- Idea 3: find node with minimum non-negative `(cur - node.end)` or `(cur - node.start)`
  The idea here is to generalize over what "being close to a node" means - it just means we're inside of it, of close to the end of it. So rather than trying to descend onto a node, we can thinking of this as scanning laterally and figuring out which node "we last saw" prior to the cursor, and choosing that one.
  - `{{ a | b: 1 + ¬¶  }}` finds the empty expression on the RHS of `1 +` as expected
  - `{{ (a | ¬¶ ) + 1 }}` finds the pipe `a |` as expect
  - `{{ ¬¶a = 1 }}` finds a property write or an interpolation, depending how you treat the cursor position
  - `{{ a | b: (¬¶) }}` finds the empty expression in `()`
  - `"a = 1; b = ¬¶2"` finds a property write or an interpolation, depending how you treat the cursor position
  I think this approach works and is intuitive, hence I recommend going this route.

Curious to hear others' thoughts.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ivy LS: Context determination (for local completions)" (#39451)

Issues.Title: i18n: change default locale from english without generating localized bundles

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package

Angular v10

### Description

Setting the `angular.json` i18n source locale doesn't change the `LOCALE_ID` that is injected to the specified language if compiled with `--localize=false`. As my applications native language is german, this breaks quite a few things that rely on this token for e.g. API calls.

Everything works just fine in any language if localization is enabled. But this slows down the build process significantly because one has to wait for the "Localized bundle generation complete." message.

I would like to be able to generate the "native" language version of my app without running the whole localization build step. If this would be set via a different option in `angular.json` or something entirely else thats also fine.

* This is somewhat related to issue #27883, the solutions proposed there all lead to the localized bundles being generated.
* I tried to manually inject my `de` locale [as hinted in the official docs for `LOCALE_ID`](https://angular.io/api/core/LOCALE_ID). But I didn't manage to ever get `de` being injected even if `registerLocaleData(localeDe, "de");` has been called before.

Issues.Body: Something confuses me about the `preOrderHooks` array within `TView` objects. The other hook arrays follow this exact same pattern. I noticed that in several places where the hook arrays are updated, they are always updated with the directive index and hook function simultaneously, enforcing the encoding of even indices as directive indices and odd indices as hook functions. ‚Ä¶ult to new projects

The ViewEngine message extraction generates a variety of legacy formats
for extracted message ids. These formats have a number of issues related
to whitespace handling and reliance upon information inside the original
HTML of a template. The new message format is more resilient to things
like whitespace changes, and can be generated directly from calls to
`$localize`, which allows messages in application code to have the same
id as identical messages in templates.

As a first step in migrating projects away from the legacy id format
for i18n messages, this commit updates newly generated projects to turn
off the legacy ids.

In the future the default will be flipped and this can be removed.
Eventually the legacy message id support will be removed altogether,
probably in sync with removal of ViewEngine.

# üêû Bug report

`@ngtools/webpack` (`AngularCompilerPlugin`)

No

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/13643 added a warning message when the TS compiler is configured to emit ES2017 or higher, due to https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/13477. I asked on https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/31730 and it sounds like we need a separate ticket to track this since the linked PR and issue are both auto-closed. Pick any project you have lying around that uses `AngularCompilerPlugin`, change `compilerOptions.target` in the `tsconfig.json` to `ES2017`, and build.  If you were building it with the CLI you'd see `Warning: Zone.js does not support native async/await in ES2017` on the console, but not with the plugin.

## üåç Your Environment

`@ngtools-webpack` 10.1.2, but I don't see any relevant changes in the recent 11+ builds.

Issues.Body:

Issues.Title: bug(overlay): Push calculation is wrong with FlexibleConnectedPositionStrategy
Issues.Body:
## Bug description

Push calculation is wrong [in this line](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/0b2d150339fb6e5736ea199bc62785ec1d2e8928/src/cdk/overlay/position/flexible-connected-position-strategy.ts#L614). Maybe in the next lines also, but I did not check it yet.

I tried to add an element, that perfectly fits, but I could not. I realized that the double of the original margin is used on the right side. I used LTR.

### Input

Take a document, that has 400px width. The margin is 20px on the viewport of the overlay. I tried to add one overlay at (300, 20) with size of (80,40). I will use this in the stackblitz and in the calculations.

#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ardamx

![overlay](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6360699/97225389-df307d00-17d2-11eb-8399-e5a339d20aca.gif)

As you see the overlay is positioned well at the begining. 100px is the container. 80px is the overlay. 10-80-10 is well positioned.

If the body element is 420px width, the position is right. 0-80-20.

If the body is shrinked more to 400px, the position will not be 0-80-20, however it could fit.

#### Expected Behavior

pushX to be 0 in this case. The element should fit without pushing it. The margin should be 20px on the right, too.

#### Actual Behavior

start.x is 300, the width is 80 as these are given. The viewport width is 360px (=400px-2*20px).

pushX will be -20 as overflowRight is 20. This is calculated by 300+80-360=20.

This is wrong. The element can fit without pushing it. The margin is now the double of the originally given, which is 40px in this case.

#### Environment

- Angular: 10.1.3
- CDK/Material: 10.2.5
- Browser(s): Chrome (Could be any)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS (Could be any)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(overlay): Push calculation is wrong with FlexibleConnectedPositionStrategy" (#20890)
